name: Khalil Center
mission: Our wellness centers integrate Islamic spiritual approaches into professional psychology to help achieve optimal, holistic health by providing a wide variety of mental health services.
theoryOfChange: Khalil Center utilizes an "integrative treatment framework" or "Traditional Islamically Integrated Psychotherapy (TIIP) model" to guide its approach to mental healthcare. This framework outlines Islamic beliefs regarding health, pathology, human ontology, and epistemology, and integrates modern psychological science to address psychological, spiritual, and communal health. The TIIP model emphasizes psychological reconstruction, behavioral reformation, and spiritual elevation. It serves as a structured approach for integrating contemporary behavioral science into an inherently Islamic framework, rooted in an Islamic epistemological and ontological framework.

evaluationSources: Practice-based evidence study published in Spirituality in Clinical Practice
Research published in Journal of Muslim Mental Health

zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://khalilcenter.com/donate/zakat (Source: https://khalilcenter.com/donate/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

all_citations.claim: The organization maintains a program expense ratio of 71.2% and 2.4 months of working capital.
The Khalil Center is zakat-eligible and applies zakat to specific asnaf categories for clinical care.
The organization reported total revenue of $2,272,898 and a fundraising efficiency of $0.01 per $1 raised.
The center provides clinical appointments and professional training scholarships.
The organization delivers psychotherapy sessions and didactic trainings.
The foundation provides various giving methods and donation options for supporters.

Enhancing data transparency to improve overall confidence scores

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation shows high alignment with donor interests by offering Zakat-eligible services that follow specific asnaf categories [2][6]. Its focus on global health and mental wellness addresses an urgent cause with a track record of consistent clinical service delivery [4][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a capacity-building approach by delivering psychotherapy sessions and professional training scholarships [4][5]. While it maintains a program expense ratio of 71.2%, the cost per beneficiary is approximately $907.87, and the charity operates with 2.4 months of working capital [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Khalil Foundation integrates spiritual wellness with modern psychology to provide comprehensive mental health services to the community.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.01 per $1 raised

Diverse programming spanning psychotherapy sessions and didactic trainings
baseline_narrative.summary: The Khalil Foundation, operating as the Khalil Center, provides clinical mental health services, community education, and professional training rooted in Islamic principles [1][4]. The organization reported a total revenue of $2,272,898 and maintains a commitment to accessibility through zakat-eligible clinical programs [2][3].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support culturally competent, Islamically integrated mental health services and fulfill zakat obligations by subsidizing clinical care for those in need.
donor_motivations: Care deeply about mental health destigmatization in the Muslim community
Want to fulfill zakat obligations by supporting healthcare access
Value organizations that integrate traditional Islamic principles with modern clinical practice
giving_considerations: The organization relies heavily on earned program service revenue alongside donations
Working capital reserves are relatively lean
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fund international emergency relief or those looking for organizations with large financial endowments.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization tracks and publishes clear output metrics (e.g., session counts, training numbers) but lacks rigorous third-party impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Provides clinical services and professional training to improve mental health outcomes in the Muslim community.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Tracking clinical sessions and training outcomes ensures that community needs are being met effectively.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Lean reserves and high demand for subsidized clinical services indicate strong capacity to absorb additional funding.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with highly efficient development costs, spending only <cite id="5">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>.
The center has achieved significant clinical reach, delivering <cite id="4">70,136 psychotherapy sessions</cite>.
The organization provides <cite id="3">zakat-eligible clinical programs</cite>, aligning strongly with Muslim donor values.

strengths_deep_dive: The Khalil Foundation demonstrates a strong commitment to accessible mental health care within the Muslim community. By maintaining a <cite id="2">71.2% program expense ratio</cite>, the organization ensures the vast majority of its <cite id="1">$2,272,898 in total revenue</cite> directly supports clinical services and community education. Their ability to deliver <cite id="4">70,136 psychotherapy sessions</cite> highlights their operational capacity and the high demand for Islamically integrated psychological services.
rich_narrative.summary: The Khalil Foundation, operating as the Khalil Center, integrates spiritual wellness with modern psychology to provide comprehensive mental health services. Founded in <cite id="8">2010</cite>, the organization reported <cite id="1">$2,272,898 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. The center is highly efficient in its development efforts, spending just <cite id="5">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>. It directs a significant portion of its funding to direct services, maintaining a <cite id="2">71.2% program expense ratio</cite>. The organization offers <cite id="3">zakat-eligible clinical programs</cite> to ensure accessibility for underserved populations, and recently reported delivering <cite id="4">70,136 psychotherapy sessions</cite> and <cite id="9">324 didactic trainings</cite>.
